To meet demands of smart heating development, the novel dynamic regulation methods of heating systems need to be pursued. This paper presents a model predictive control (MPC) approach for room temperature regulation in multi-zone buildings. Among them, a) For heating systems with nonlinearity and large time delay, a hybrid optimization algorithm consisting of the improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm and Newton-Raphson (NR) method in online optimization of MPC for a single zone building is proposed. Compared with the quadratic programming method, it can identify successfully the optimal control vector. b) A distributed MPC approach is presented for multi-zone buildings existing hydraulic coupling. Firstly, Nash-optimization acts on searching the global equilibrium point in the distributed structure, then the hybrid optimization algorithm works in the online optimization of these local MPCs. Compared with the decentralized MPC, the control performance is improved through co-operating and communicating between subsystems via network to share information related to their future behavior. Besides, the global performance index in the distributed MPC is redefined as the weighted sum of energy consumption and thermal comfort, which provides the possibility to eliminate quickly the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop in heating systems and reduce energy consumption. Newton-Raphson RC Resistance capacity 1 Introduction In northern China, urban heating is an infrastructure-based industry related to daily living [1]. It is necessary to reduce energy consumption while ensuring stable heating performance. In 2014, China's building energy consumption accounted for more than 30% of the country's total energy consumption [2]. Further, the heating energy consumption accounted for nearly 40% of China's building energy consumption [3,4]. Simultaneously, the accelerated ecological civilization construction in China [5] and the fifth generation of district heating features introduced in the EU [6] will be required to significantly reduce the pollution and thereby improve the quality of the environment [7]. Based on significant changes in the energy utilization strategies for the establishment of low-carbon energy systems, the novel heating forms and dynamic regulation methods of heating system have been pursued. Therefore, the development and implementation of effective control techniques for the heating system is of primary importance [8]. During the last two decades, model predictive control (MPC) as a popular class of control strategies for heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems has been largely investigated recently [9–14]. A literature review emphasizing the theory and applications of MPC for HVAC systems was presented in [9]. A classification for control methods in HVAC systems was given and brief details of each method were showed, such as classical control, hard control, soft control and hybrid control. Besides, factors affecting MPC performance (including model, optimization technique, prediction horizon, control horizon, constraints, and cost function) were analyzed in [9]. Energy saving efforts in a building heating system by applying MPC and using weather predictions were discussed depending on various factors, mainly insulation level and outside temperature in [10]. The thermal dynamics of the room were presented by RC modeling and the encouraging results were obtained in the real building. The energy efficiency in Integrated Room Automation (IRA) while respecting occupant comfort was investigated using the control method combining MPC with weather predictions in [11,12]. And three different control strategies were compared: Rule-Based Control (RBC), Deterministic MPC (DMPC), and Stochastic MPC (SMPC). Then it was found that SMPC results in much smaller diurnal temperature variations by the large-scale simulation study, so it was considered more favorable. An optimal predictive control strategy for radiant floor district heating systems was studied in [13]. Simulation results indicated potential energy savings of approx.10% compared to the PI control strategy. MPC cooperating with a set-point optimizer which decides the set-point online to minimize the energy used was studied in a residential building with an underfloor heating system [14]. The results showed that the set-point optimizer can further reduce energy used by about 300 kWh annually. Therefore, MPC can provide a solution to handle time-varying disturbances, wide operating conditions, actuator constraints, and variable price structures in HVAC systems [9]. MPC is an on-line constrained optimization method, based on an iterative receding horizon control strategy [15]. Therefore, on-line optimization is a significant link in predictive control. MPC cost function often defines a very complex, non-linear, non-convex search space in HVAC systems [15]. Traditionally, the quadratic programming method was applied in identifying an optimal control vector [14,16]. But that the cost function should be monotonically changing in mathematical programming methods [17] and that the initial feasible solution is reasonably selected needs to be required [16–18], therefore on-line optimization turns out to be suitable for heuristic approaches [15]. A novel Differential Discrete Particle Swarm Optimization (DDPSO) for MPC was proposed in [15]. Compared with a standard particle swarm algorithm, an encouraging performance was obtained by DDPSO that was suggested to apply in context where a fast and real-time reaction was needed. A hybrid algorithm by combining particle swarm optimization (PSO) with sequential quadratic programming (SQP) to handle the optimization part of the nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) was proposed in [16]. The heuristic PSO algorithm in cooperation with the powerful local minimizing SQP algorithm can quickly find these optimizing solutions and also can satisfy the constrains. As the conventional MPC attempted to minimize a quadratic cost over an extended control horizon, chaos particle swarm optimization (CPSO) was used to perform model predictive controller for nonlinear process with constraints in [18]. The simulations of a continuous stirred-tank reactor were used to demonstrate the practicality and effectiveness of the identification and control scheme. A genetic algorithm (GA) was used to solve the on-line optimization problem of multiple parameters in VAV air-conditioning systems in [19]. The method was tested and evaluated in a simulated living environment under various weather conditions. And tests showed that GA was a convenient tool in searching the optimal settings to minimize the overall system cost for on-line control application of air-conditioning systems. A Hybrid Model Predictive Control (HMPC) strategy was presented to control solar-assisted HVAC systems with on-site thermal energy generation and storage [20]. The proposed control strategy was organized in two hierarchical levels, of which the high-level acted on selecting the operating mode of the HVAC system and the low-level was used for each operating model optimization. The simulation and experimental results demonstrated the high performance achievable using an HMPC approach to optimizing complex multimode HVAC systems in residential buildings. A hybrid algorithm consisting of chaotic particle swarm optimization (CPSO) algorithm and sequential quadratic programming (SQP) techniques was developed for solving the economic dispatch (ED) problems [21]. The proposed method was tested on various power systems with 6, 13, 15, and 40 power plants with and without wind power to evaluate its effectiveness. Compared with state-of-the-art heuristic optimization methods, the proposed method improved the solution of ELD problem. Besides, particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is widely used in identifying model parameters and gaining some promising solutions such as CPSO [22], PSO–SQP [23], FAPSO–VDE [24], the improved CPSO [25], IPSO-ANN [26] and DSPSO–TSA [27]. In this work, some significant improvements are added in the standard PSO algorithm, such as unconstrained optimal control vector and adaptive inertia weight. And Newton-Raphson (NR) method is introduced to search accurate solutions within the basins, in which second-order information of the cost function is made full use comparing with the quadratic programming method [28–30]. Therefore, one of the tasks in this paper is that a hybrid optimization algorithm consisting of the improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm and Newton-Raphson (NR) method in identifying an optimal control vector of MPC for a single zone building is studied. As the heating system serves multiple rooms in residential building, another task is that we extend the above-mentioned MPC approach to multi-zone buildings. As thermal coupling [8,9] between the zones caused in the thermal transient and hydraulic coupling, the decentralized control structure does not offer good control performances resulting in temperature swings in the zone due to heating of neighboring zones at different set points [8,9,31]. On the other hand, the centralized implementation for which the computational demand grows exponentially with the size of the system is very expensive for large scale buildings [8,9,31–34]. Therefore, the solution is to design a distributed structure in which the local MPCs can cooperate and communicate with each other via network to share the zone information to achieve the objective of the whole system [9,31–33]. A one-step distributed algorithm was proposed for building temperature regulation using electrical convectors in a large-scale building in [8]. The distributed method exploited the output coupling between the subsystems, improving the convergence and offering a high degree of performance with a low computational demand. An efficient distributed MPC scheme based on Nash optimality for a single-duct VAV air-conditioning system was presented in [33]. Simulation results demonstrated that the performance of the Nash-optimization enhanced distributed MPC was better than that of the fully decentralized MPC and was close to that of the centralized MPC. A distributed MPC methodology to manage energy resources for a set of consumer subsystems was studied in [35]. And a good performance was obtained by the proposed distributed controller in Hardware-in-the-loop experiments with an air-conditioning thermal solar plant. However, only heat transmission through internal walls, that is, output coupling, as thermal coupling between the zones is considered in the previous literature [8], ignoring hydraulic coupling, that is, input coupling. In the heating networks, the hydraulic conditions between any two parallel loops strongly couple that are not limited in only between two adjacent rooms [36,37]. And the main reason that the thermal dynamic characteristics coupled between any two rooms served by the same heating system is severe non-linear hydraulic connections. Therefore, this work presents a distributed MPC based on Nash optimality in which hydraulic coupling mainly is concerned. Simultaneously, to minimize the energy consumption without reducing the occupants’ comfort, the global performance index in the distributed MPC is redefined as the weighted sum of energy consumption and thermal comfort. Simulations and performance comparison are shown based on energy consumption and the time to eliminate the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop [38]. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a MPC method based on hybrid optimization algorithm for a single zone building; Section 3 shows a distributed MPC approach based on Nash optimality for multi-zone buildings; Section 4 shows the simulation results and analysis of proposed methods; and Section 5 gives our conclusions. 2 MPC for a single zone building In this section, MPC for a single zone building is presented. Firstly, a thermal dynamic model of indoor air is established according to the energy conservation equation. Next, the procedures of MPC are described in brief. Lastly, a hybrid optimization algorithm in on-line optimization is proposed. 2.1 Thermal dynamic model of indoor air There are several heat balance relationships related to indoor air. Therefore, the thermal dynamic models of radiator, indoor air and envelops need to be established. The physical model is shown in Fig. 1 . 2.1.1 Modeling assumptions Generally, to investigate the main thermal dynamic characteristic of indoor air, the following assumptions are used in physical models. a) The heat medium is considered as homogeneous one-dimensional incompressible fluid with a volume expansion coefficient of zero. b) As compared with the heat convection, the heat medium conduction along the pipeline and the energy dissipation are relatively weak. Hence, these terms can be neglected. c) As the heat capacity of the radiator’s metal shell is far smaller than that of heat medium, the former can be neglected. d) The effects of thermal radiation and free heat generated by the heat-dissipating equipment and personnel activities on room temperature are corrected using the “feedback correction” link in MPC. Most of the abovementioned assumptions have been applied in most literatures about dynamic thermal model for their rationality [39–44]. 2.1.2 Mathematical model The energy conservation equation of fluid can be written as the following form [39,41]: (1) ρ c d T d τ = ∂ ∂ x i λ ∂ T ∂ x i + φ + β T d P d τ + q wherein, T denotes the fluid temperature; ρ represents the fluid density; c indicates the specific heat of fluid; λ represents the fluid thermal conductivity; φ denotes the energy dissipation term; β represents the volume expansion coefficient of fluid; P represents the fluid pressure; q denotes the internal heat source term; τ and x are time and space coordinates respectively. Eq. (1) is simplified based on the above assumptions. The thermal dynamic models of radiator, indoor air and envelops are established respectively. The radiator is considered as the control volume, and the thermal dynamics of indoor air can be lumped as a thermal capacity, the energy balance equations can be expressed as [39,40,44]: (2) V r d ρ w c w ∂ T m ∂ τ = G w ρ w c w T w , s - T w , r + k r d F r d T i - T m (3) V r m ρ i c i ∂ T i ∂ t = k r d F r d T m - T i + h i F e T e 1 - T i + G o ρ o c o T o - T i (4) T m = T w , s + T w , r 2 wherein, T w , T i , T w , s and T w , r represent the temperature of heat medium, indoor air, supplied and returned water; T e 1 and T o represent the internal surface temperature of envelop and outdoor air temperature; F r d and V r d represent the heat transfer area and volume of radiator respectively; V r m denotes the room volume; F e represents the envelope area; ρ w , c w and G w represent the density, specific heat and flow of heat medium respectively; ρ i and ρ o indicate the indoor and outdoor air density; c i and c o represent the specific heat of indoor and outdoor air; G o denotes cold air infiltration; k r d represents the heat transfer coefficient of the radiator; h i indicates the convective heat transfer coefficient between the indoor air and envelop, which is given by [45], (5) h i = λ i L c N u (6) Nu = 0.825 + 0.387 G r P r 1 / 6 1 + 0.492 / P r 9 / 16 8 / 27 2 (7) Gr = g β T i - T e 1 L c 3 υ i 2 wherein, λ i and υ i represent the thermal conductivity and kinematic viscosity of the indoor air respectively; L c denotes the characteristic length; Nu is Nusselt number; Gr is Grashof number; Pr is Prandtl number; g is the acceleration of gravity; β represents the volume expansion coefficient. Heat balance equations of envelops are expressed by the lumped model [44,46] (Fig. 2 (a)). A comprehensive heat transfer coefficient is considered in the transparent envelopes (Fig. 2 (b)). The thermal conductivity resistance can be expressed as [41], (13) R e j = δ e j λ e j wherein, λ e j represents the thermal conductivity of the j -layer j = 2 , 3 , ⋯ , z envelope. 2.2 Model predictive control In this section, the room temperature MPC approach for a single zone is shown in brief. Firstly, the prediction horizon, control horizon and total number of time steps are set as I , M, N respectively, wherein I ≤ M ≤ N . The choice of prediction horizon must consider the enough time for the control system to change the indoor temperature up to the desired setpoint [8]. A small prediction horizon means less computational demands but a loss in optimality simultaneously [8]. An analysis of the prediction horizon influence over the control performances can be found in [48]. In this paper, considering the less thermal inertia of buildings, we used a time step as 60 s, then the prediction horizon and control horizon are set as 10- and 5-times time step respectively. 2.2.1 Modeling assumptions a) The control sequence remains unchanged outside the control horizon [8], i.e. Δ G w τ + j = 0 , I ≤ j ≤ M ; b) The measurable disturbances remain unchanged in the prediction horizon, i.e. Δ T o τ + j = 0 , 1 ≤ j ≤ M - 1 . 2.2.2 Predictive control model Firstly, the partial differential equations in section 2.1 are discretized using the finite differential method [39]. The time derivatives of the temperatures of heat medium, indoor air and envelopes can be replaced by difference quotients [39]. Next, to reduce or eliminate static errors at room temperature, the abovementioned models are integrated and rearranged as incremental models in vector form. The detailed calculated values of parameters are seen in Appendix A. 2.2.3 Cost function The cost function is defined as the weighted sum of tracking error and control effort, i.e. the predicted output is hypothesized to be closer to the reference input, and consideration given to the size of Δ G w τ is as small as possible [9,49]. Then, due to the receding horizon control principle [50], only the first element of the optimal control vector is applied to the system [16]. 2.2.4 Feedback correction Due to the model mismatch and environmental disturbances, the predicted room temperature may deviate from the actual value [51]. Therefore, real-time information is used to correct the predicted value [52]. The difference between the actual output and predicted output is employed as a correction value to rectify the predicted values. (21) cor τ + 1 = T i a - T i τ + 1 (22) T i c o r = T i τ + 1 + F cor τ + 1 (23) F = def f 1 f 2 ⋯ f M T wherein, T i a , cor τ + 1 , T i c o r , and F represent the actual output value and correction value of the predictive result at time step τ + 1, the corrected predictive output vector and the correction vector with the first element f 1 = 1 , respectively. 2.3 Online optimization based on hybrid optimization algorithm For the online optimization in predictive control, the cost function can be transformed into the solution for quadratic programming problem traditionally [53,54]. (24) f i t τ = 2 × 1 2 Δ G w τ T H e Δ G w τ + g T Δ G w τ + c o n s t (25) H e = B u 1 T Q T Q B u 1 + R T R (26) g = - B u 1 T Q T Q T s e t τ + 1 - I T i τ - Ψ τ wherein, H e and g represent the Hessian matrix and gradient vector, respectively. If the constraint conditions aren’t considered, the optimal control vector will be obtained [53–55]. (29) Δ G w ∗ = B u 1 T Q T Q B u 1 + R T R - 1 B u 1 T Q T Q T s e t τ + 1 - I T i τ - Ψ τ However, the mathematical programming method requires that the cost function should be monotonically changing [17] and the choice of the initial feasible solution seriously affect the optimal results [16–18]. Therefore, in this work, a hybrid optimization algorithm combining the improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm and Newton-Raphson (NR) method in identifying the optimal control vector is proposed. The following hybrid optimization method in online optimization is described in detail. 2.3.1 Newton-Raphson method The Newton-Raphson (NR) method belongs to mathematical programming method. This sophisticated method has been proposed in many literatures, such as Refs. [36,37,56]. The iterative formula is as follows [57]: (30) X τ + 1 = X τ - J τ - 1 E τ T (31) E τ = Q B u 1 X τ - Ψ τ R X τ where, X τ represents the input vector in the τ-th iteration; E τ denotes the error vector in the τ-th iteration; J τ is the Jacobian matrix in the τ-th iteration. (32) J τ = Q B u 1 R The NR method can make full use of the second-order information of the cost function to improve operational efficiency, but its performance depends excessively on the initial starting point. Therefore, the particle swarm optimization algorithm is introduced. 2.3.2 Improved particle swarm optimization algorithm The PSO algorithm is one of the modern heuristic algorithms, which searches for the optimal value with cooperation between individuals [58,59]. Due to its simpler structure and extensive scalability, it has been widely used in model parameter optimization. Of course, it should be noted that there are some shortcomings in the PSO algorithm. For example, the premature particles that become trapped in locally optimal solutions emerge in the later evolution [16,18,57,59]. Therefore, some improvements are added to the algorithm. a) Unconstrained optimal control vector Here, when randomly initializing the positions of particles, the unconstrained optimal control vector (Eq. (29)) is doped into particle swarm, as the position of one particle. If it just meets the constraint conditions, the algorithm will be terminated immediately. b) Adaptive inertia weight Besides, the inertia weight ( w ) for the process of updating the speed of the particles determines the particle’s inheritance from the current velocity. A larger w favors global optimization, while a smaller w favors local optimization [60]. Comparison of linear [61], random and adaptive strategies for fixed w identified the adaptive w algorithm as having the fastest convergence speed and good precision stability (Fig. 5 in Section 4.1). Therefore, the adaptive w strategy is adopted using Eq. (33). (33) w = w m i n - w m a x - w m i n × fit τ - fit m i n τ fit a v g τ - fit m i n τ , fit τ ≤ fit a v g τ w m a x , fit τ > fit a v g τ wherein, w m i n and w m a x represent the minimum and the maximum w , respectively; fit m i n τ and fit a v g τ represent the minimum and average fitness values in the particle swarm, respectively. 2.3.3 Algorithm operation steps The operational steps for the hybrid optimization algorithm are as follows: a) Initialize parameters of IPSO algorithm The number of particles, the maximum number of iterations of the algorithm, the upper and lower bounds of search space and velocity are represented by pn, maxgen1, Δ G w m i n and Δ G w m a x . The positions X α , d τ and velocity V α , d τ of the particles are randomly initialized. The current position is considered as its personal best position p b e s t α , d τ . The best position discovered by the whole population g b e s t d τ is obtained from particles’ personal best positions [57]. The position of the α-th particle, X α , d τ , is expressed as follows: (34) X α , d τ = x α , 1 τ x α , 2 τ ⋯ x α , d τ = Δ G w τ T The iterative formula for the standard PSO algorithm is calculated as follows [57]: (35) V α , d τ + 1 = w V α , d τ + a 1 r 1 p b e s t α , d τ - V α , d τ + 1 + a 2 r 2 ( g b e s t d τ - V α , d τ + 1 ) (36) X α , d τ + 1 = X α , d τ + V α , d τ + 1 wherein, d is the particle dimension, which is equal to the control horizon, i.e. d = I; a 1 and a 2 are learning factors; r 1 and r 2 are random numbers between [0,1]. b) Update the particle state The velocity and position of each particle are updated with Eq. (35) and Eq. (36) respectively [57], then assessed whether the updated velocity and position exceeded the particle velocity range Δ G w m i n , Δ G w m a x . c) Evaluate the quality of particles Eq. (15) is employed to calculate the particle fitness value [62]. In case the particle fitness value is less than the current individual best fitness value that is f i t X α , d τ + 1 < f i t p b e s t α , d τ , p b e s t α , d τ + 1 is adjusted to X α , d τ + 1 . In case the individual best fitness value of this particle is less than the current best fitness value discovered by the whole population, namely f i t p b e s t α , d τ + 1 < f i t g b e s t d τ , g b e s t d τ + 1 is adjusted to p b e s t α , d τ + 1 , otherwise g b e s t d τ + 1 remains the same. d) Check the termination criterion of IPSO algorithm The iteration number is updated and assessed whether the current iteration number reached the preset maximum number. If τ > maxgen1, turn to e), else proceeded to b). e) Initialize parameters of NR algorithm Set the accuracy index as esp and the maximum number of iterations as maxgen2. The ultimate best position of IPSO algorithm, g b e s t d τ , is considered as the initial value of NR method [57]. f) Evaluate performance index for optimization Eq. (15) is utilized to calculate the fitness value. If the current fitness value is less than the accuracy index, namely f i t X τ < e s p , terminate the algorithm, otherwise go on. g) Update the input vector Jacobian matrix is calculated using Eq. (32). Eq. (30) is employed for updating the input vector. h) Check the termination criterion of NR algorithm Update the iteration number, and determine whether the current iteration number has reached the preset maximum number. If τ < maxgen2, turn to g), otherwise terminate the algorithm. The flow chart of the hybrid optimization algorithm is shown in Fig. 3 . 3 Distributed MPC for multi-zone buildings This section will generalize the MPC approach proposed above to multi-zone buildings. In heating networks, the hydraulic coupling between the parallel loops is not negligible. This influence not only exists between adjacent rooms, but also any two rooms served by the same heating system [36–38]. However, at present, the most control structure used in large scale buildings is a decentralized one. In this case room temperature is regulated by an independent controller. The coupling effect is not considered in the control input signal, which is no longer optimal, resulting in fluctuations in room temperature [8,9,31]. In this section, a distributed MPC is implemented for multi-zone buildings. Firstly, Nash-optimization is developed to enhance the control performance in distributed structure. Next, the hydraulic dynamic model of a heating system of residential building is briefly established to determine the coupling relationships between the parallel loops. Lastly, to minimize the energy consumption without reducing the occupants’ comfort, the cost function in distributed MPC is redefined. 3.1 Distributed MPC based on Nash optimality The distributed MPC is structured as a decentralized law, with a local controller for each subsystem [8]. These local MPCs can co-operate and communicate with each other via network to share information related to their future behaviour [32]. Since the protocol of mutual communication and information exchange is adequately considered [32,33], this approach can efficiently improve control performance and guarantee the Nash equilibrium or global optimality [8]. The distributed MPC structure diagram is shown in Fig. 4 (a). An optimization formulation in large-scale systems can be decomposed into that of several small co-operative agents [32]. It is assumed that the behavior of the whole system is expressed by n agents. At time instant τ , the predictive output of the j-th agent is described as [32,33], (37) T i , j τ + 1 = I T i , j τ + B u 1 , j Δ G w , t τ + Ψ j τ (38) Δ G w , t τ = Δ G w , 1 τ ⋯ Δ G w , k τ ⋯ Δ G w , n τ T (39) B u 1 , j = B u 1 , j 1 ⋯ B u 1 , j k ⋯ B u 1 , j n (40) B u 1 , j k = B u 1 , k = j μ jk B u 1 , k ≠ j wherein, Δ G w , t τ represents control vectors of all agents; B u 1 , j denotes the control input-to-state matrices of the j-th agent; μ jk is defined as the hydraulic coupling factor between agent k and j . It can be seen that the output of each agent is related to all the input variables due to the input coupling. Therefore, the local performance index for the j-th agent is expressed as [8,32,33], (41) fit j τ = ‖ Q T s e t , j τ + 1 - T i , j τ + 1 ‖ 2 + ‖ R Δ G w , j τ ‖ 2 + ∑ k = 1 , k ≠ j n ‖ R Δ G w , k τ ‖ 2 Such a distributed control problem with various objectives can be solved employing Nash optimal concept. For the j-th agent, the Nash optimal solution satisfy the following relation [32]. (42) fit j ∗ Δ G w , 1 N ⋯ Δ G w , j N ⋯ Δ G w , n N ≤ fit j Δ G w , 1 N ⋯ Δ G w , j - 1 N , Δ G w , j τ , Δ G w , j + 1 N ⋯ Δ G w , n N wherein, Δ G w , j N represents the Nash optimal solution of the j-th agent. Each agent can’t change its control decision Δ G w , j N after the Nash equilibrium point is reached, otherwise the local performance index fit j ∗ will degrade [32]. If other agents’ Nash optimal solutions have been known, the local performance index of each agent will be only related to its own control decision. (43) fit j τ = min Δ G w , j τ fit j τ | Δ G w , k N k = 1 , 2 , ⋯ , n | k ≠ j To obtain the Nash optimal solution of the j-th agent, other agents’ Nash optimal solutions need to be known, so that the whole system could arrive at Nash equilibrium in this coupling decision process [32]. The steps of obtaining Nash optimal solution in distributed MPC are as follows [8,32]: a) Initial estimation At sampling time instant τ , let the iterative index l = 0 and set the accuracy index as esp. Each agents’ initial estimation of the input variables Δ G w , j l is given and shared with each other. b) Local optimization Each agent solves its optimal problem independently based on the above hybrid optimization algorithm to obtain its solution Δ G w , j l + 1 . c) Convergence evaluation Each agent checks if the given error accuracy is satisfied. If there exist Δ G w , j l + 1 - Δ G w , j l ≤ esp j = 1 , 2 , ⋯ , n , then terminate the iteration and turn to d), else let l = l + 1, Δ G w , j l = Δ G w , j l + 1 and proceeded to b). d) Receding horizon control Only the first element of the Nash optimal solution is applied to each agent, i.e. Δ G w , j ∗ = 1 , 0 , ⋯ , 0 1 × I Δ G w , j l + 1 . Move horizon to the next sampling time, that is, τ = τ + 1, and turn to a). 3.2 Hydraulic dynamic model The coupling relationships between the parallel loops are described by the hydraulic coupling factor between subsystems. Therefore, the hydraulic dynamic model of a heating system of residential building is briefly described in this section. Firstly, graph theory (Fig. 4) is applied to model the hydraulic conditions of the heating networks [37,63]. (44) B k G b r a = 0 (45) C f Δ P b r a - H b r a = 0 (46) G b r a T = G b r a 1 , G b r a 2 , ⋯ , G b r a n (47) Δ P b r a T = Δ P b r a 1 , Δ P b r a 2 , ⋯ , Δ P b r a n wherein, B k represents the basic incidence matrix which is m - 1 × n order [37,42]; G b r a denotes the branch flow array; C f represents the independent loop matrix which is n - m + 1 × n order [37,42]; n denotes branch numbers; m represents node numbers; Δ P b r a denotes the branch pressure drops array; H b r a represents the branch pump head array. The term in H b r a is zero unless there is a pump installed in the corresponding branch [36]. For a certain branch j , the pressure drop can be is calculated by the Darcy–Weisbach formula [37]. (48) Δ P b r a j = S j G w j G w j + ρ w j g L j sin γ j (49) S j = S p j + S v j (50) S p j = 8 ρ w j π 2 D j 4 f j L j D j + ξ j (51) S v j = f θ j G w j q - 2 wherein, S j , S p j , S v j , L j and D j represent the hydraulic impedance, pipe hydraulic impedance, valve hydraulic impedance, pipe length and diameter of the branch j ; f ( θ j ) represents the hydraulic characteristics state equation of valve [64]; q is an index varying with the flow state [64]; γ j denotes the angle between branch j and horizontal axis; ξ j denotes the local resistance coefficient; f j denotes the Darcy friction coefficient, which is obtained easily in [63,64]. Therefore, the hydraulic coupling relationship between adjacent branches can be obtained based on graph theory. (52) Δ G w , j + 1 τ = μ j j + 1 Δ G w , j τ (53) μ j j + 1 = S j + 1 n τ - 1 S j τ - 1 G w , j τ - 1 S J + 1 n τ - 1 S j + 1 τ - 1 G w , j + 1 τ - 1 + Δ S j + 1 n τ S J + 1 n τ - 1 - Δ S J + 1 n τ S j + 1 n τ - 1 ∑ k = j + 1 n G w , k τ - 1 2 + Δ S j τ S j + 1 n τ - 1 G w , j τ - 1 G w , j τ - 1 - Δ S j + 1 τ S J + 1 n τ - 1 G w , j + 1 τ - 1 G w , j + 1 τ - 1 2 S J + 1 n τ - 1 S j + 1 τ - 1 G w , j + 1 τ - 1 Δ G w , j τ wherein, S j + 1 n τ - 1 or S J + 1 n τ - 1 denotes the hydraulic impedance of branches j or J to n at time step τ -1. The hydraulic coupling relationship between any two branches can be derived from Eq. (53). 3.3 Global performance index The global performance index is described as the minimization of energy consumption and the maximization of thermal comfort in heating systems. They are two competing objectives, and a trade-off must be found by placing weights on these factors in the cost function [9]. The cost function in distributed MPC is defined as, (54) f i t τ = ∑ j = 1 n fit j τ + ‖ w H s y s τ ‖ 2 wherein, w represents the energy consumption weight. H s y s τ denotes the pump head of system at time step τ . For a certain branch j , when the regulating valve is almost fully opened, the pressure drop is minimum at the same flow [38]. Comparing the sum of the pressure drops at full opening of valve of the branches included in each independent loop, the minimum pump head H s y s m i n can be determined. (55) Δ P b r a j m i n = S p j + lim θ = 100 % S v j G w j G w j + ρ w j g L j sin γ j (56) H s y s m i n = m a x C f Δ P b r a m i n The time when the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop is eliminated can be used as an index of thermal comfort evaluation. The most unfavorable thermodynamic loop is defined as the branch in which the regulating valve is almost fully opened, but room temperature can’t still increase up to set-point, i.e. θ ≈ 100 % and T i τ < T s e t τ [38]. When the most unfavorable loop appears in a certain branch, the thermal comfort of occupants will not be satisfied [38]. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Online optimization based on hybrid optimization algorithm In this section, the performance of the quadratic programming method and the hybrid optimization algorithm in identifying optimal control vector is compared and analyzed under the following condition: the room temperature set point is adjusted from 20 °C to 17 °C, then to 23 °C. The parameters of MPC and the hybrid optimization algorithm are presented in Tables 1–3 For the results evaluation, a control performance index is adopted. For the comfort, the average distance from reference temperature in the whole regulation is used [65], as illustrated in Eqs. (57) and (58): (57) M A E j = ∑ i = 1 N T s e t τ + i - T i τ + i N (58) MAE = ∑ j = 1 n M A E j n wherein, M A E j is the average distance from reference temperature of the j-th subsystem; N represents total number of time steps; n denotes the number of subsystems. €The variations of the heating parameters when the room temperature set point is adjusted from 20 °C to 17 °C, then to 23 °C are shown in Fig. 6 . Q s , Q d and Q c represent heat supplied to radiator, heat dissipated by the radiator and heat load of the room, respectively ((d) and (e) in Fig. 6). T e 1 T e 6 denote the temperature of each layer of envelope ((f) in Fig. 6) corresponding to Fig. 2 (a). Due to the thermal inertia of the conveying medium, heat dissipation equipment and buildings, there is a large time delay in heating system. For example, there are an obvious attenuation and delay in the envelope temperature ((f) in Fig. 6). When the room temperature set point is changed, the heat supplied to the radiator and dissipated by the radiator and the heat consumption of room can’t match each other in a short time ((d) and (e) in Fig. 6). Therefore, there is overshoot eventually resulting in divergence ((a), (b) and (c) in Fig. 6), then the optimal control vector can’t be obtained in the traditional mathematical programming technique. Fortunately, the heuristic algorithm can’t depend excessively on the initial starting point. The PSO is used to firstly explore a large space and the particles as potential solutions are free to move and sit on various valleys. And the IPSO algorithm could prevent premature particles that are trapped in the locally optimal value. Then, the best value of all the particles will be taken as the initial starting point in NR method to be fine tuned. In the end, a satisfactory result can be easily identified by NR method. Due to the small number of evolutions, time-consuming worries in the heuristic algorithms are unnecessary. And the second-order information of the cost function is taken full advantage by the NR method to enhance operational efficiency. MAE of the hybrid optimization algorithm in room temperature regulation is 0.99, which has been reduced by 35.71% compared with that of the quadratic programming method (1.54). When the room temperature reaches the set point, the system is in a quasi-equilibrium process. If there is no new external disturbance, the system will gradually reach the equilibrium state with the passage of time ((d) in Fig. 6). Therefore, the hybrid optimization algorithm can improve the optimization performance for online optimization in MPC of heating systems with nonlinearity and large time delay. 4.2 MPC for a single zone building To test the performance of MPC based on hybrid optimization algorithm, three different application scenarios are set up, according to changes in the outdoor temperature, supplied water temperature and indoor free heat. In each scenario, the room temperature is adjusted from 20 °C to 24 °C at 1200 s, then to 16 °C at 10200 s. (Table 4 ) The variations in the indoor air temperature and key heating parameters are presented in Figs. 7–10 . The predictive results, with variations in the outdoor temperature, supplied water temperature and indoor free heat are shown in Fig. 7, Fig. 8 and Fig. 9 respectively. The predictive result with multiple disturbance factors is presented in Fig. 10. No matter whether the outdoor air or supplied water temperature changes, the room temperature set point can be tracked by the predictive value without any static error ((a) in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8). It is shown that the MPC approach based on hybrid optimization algorithm has strong robustness. When the room temperature reaches the set point, the system is in a quasi-equilibrium process. With the passage of time, the heat supplied to the radiator and dissipated by the radiator and the heat consumption of room gradually become equal ((b) in Fig. 7 and (d) Fig. 8). Besides, the trends of temperature change of the inner and the outer layers of envelope are different ((c) in Fig. 7). It is indicated that the thermal insulation material has a good blocking effect on temperature wave transmission. When the free heat is generated in the room, the room temperature predictive value deviates from the set point. But it should be noted that through the “feedback correction” link the room temperature set point can be completely tracked by the correction value without any static error ((a) in Fig. 9). When the room temperature predictive value or correction value reaches the set point, the system is in a quasi-equilibrium process. Due to the indoor free heat, the heat supplied to the radiator and dissipated by the radiator trend to be equal and adaptively reduce ( Q f r e e > 0 ) or increase ( Q f r e e < 0 ) that just match the heat load of room ((b) in Fig. 9). It is proved that the MPC approach based on hybrid optimization algorithm has pretty good adaptability. When multiple disturbance factors are applied, the room temperature set point can be completely tracked by the predicted value or correction value without any static error ((a) in Fig. 10). Similarly, the heat supplied to the radiator and dissipated by the radiator can adaptively reduce or increase that just match the heat consumption of room ((d) in Fig. 10). To sum up, under various disturbance factors, a good performance can be obtained by MPC approach based on hybrid optimization algorithm in a single zone building. This approach can be extended to multi-zone buildings. 4.3 Distributed MPC for multi-zone buildings For simplicity purposes, a three-layer building equipped with three independent radiators is used in the simulations. The distributed MPC approach for multi-zone buildings is carried out under different conditions (Table 5 ). The simulation results applied by the distributed MPC approach based on Nash optimality for multi-zone buildings under different conditions are shown in Table 6 , Table 7 , Fig. 11 and Fig. 12 . Among them, the results of implementing the distributed MPC and decentralized MPC strategies respectively are shown in Table 7 and Fig. 11. The results of implementing the decentralized MPC approach with the fixed pump head are shown in Fig. 12. The performances of implementing the distributed MPC and decentralized MPC are compared and evaluated in Fig. 11. Due to the hydraulic coupling between any two agents and the lag in obtaining information in the decentralized structure, the local MPC can’t produce the current optimal control vector ((a), (c) and (d) in Fig. 11). Fortunately, the Nash equilibrium point is reached by co-operating and communicating with each other via network to share information related to their future behavior in the distributed MPC, so a good control performance is guaranteed ((a) and (b) in Fig. 11). MAE in the distributed MPC is reduced by 19.05% compared with that of the decentralized MPC (Table 6). If the energy consumption isn’t considered in the global performance index and the pump head of system is fixed, the hydraulic coupling will be mostly eliminated. When the demand for the thermal comfort decreases, the indoor air temperature can reach the desired set-point in the decentralized MPC, in which the performance is the same as the distributed MPC ((a) in Fig. 12). But the hydraulic impedance is larger due to the smaller valve opening ((b) and (c) in Fig. 12), compared with considering energy consumption in the cost function. Therefore, more energy about 29.76% throughout the operating period is wasted ( H d i s t r i b u t e d τ < H f i x e d τ ) ((d) in Fig. 12). When the demand of the thermal comfort increases, the indoor air temperature can slowly or can’t reach the desired set-point due to the limit to pump head ((a) in Fig. 12). The time when the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop occurs and lasts is longer than the former, increasing by at least 482.67%. Of course, there is no free lunch. The minimization of energy consumption and the maximization of thermal comfort are two competing objectives. To eliminate the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop as soon as possible, the pump head of system can increase instantaneously. Therefore, weights in the cost function play a crucial role in seeking an optimal scheme. To conclude, the distributed MPC offers a solution for improving the control performance of heating systems in multi-zone buildings, of which Nash-optimization acts on searching the global equilibrium point in the distributed structure, then the hybrid optimization algorithm works in the online optimization of local MPCs. Besides, the global performance index that is redefined as the weighted sum of energy consumption and thermal comfort provides the possibility to minimize the energy consumption on the premise of satisfying a desired comfort level. 5 Conclusions To meet demands of personalized heating development, an MPC strategy is designed for indoor air temperature regulation in multi-zone buildings. Firstly, for the heating system with nonlinear and large time delay characteristics, a hybrid optimization algorithm in online optimization is proposed and an MPC method based on that for a single zone building is verified. Next, the above-mentioned approach combined with a distributed structure is generalized to multi-zone buildings existing hydraulic coupling. The following conclusions are drawn: a) The performance of hybrid optimization algorithm consisting of the improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm and Newton-Raphson (NR) method can’t depend excessively on the initial feasible solution. Compared with the quadratic programming method, it is validated that it can improve the optimization performance in MPC of heating systems with nonlinearity and large time delay, in which the optimal control vector can be identified successfully and MAE is reduced by 35.71%. b) The distributed MPC approach takes the input coupling into account by information exchange between the agents, improving the control performance of heating systems in multi-zone buildings, of which hybrid optimization algorithm is used for optimization in local MPC of each agent and Nash-optimization acts on searching the global equilibrium point. It can be seen that MAE in the distributed MPC is reduced by 19.05% compared with that of the decentralized MPC. c) The global performance index in the distributed MPC is designed as the weighted sum of energy consumption and thermal comfort, which provides the possibility to eliminate quickly the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop in heating systems and reduce energy consumption. The time when the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop occurs and lasts in the distributed MPC is only 17.16% of that of the strategy with the fixed pump head. d) Future work will focus on the dynamic cost function, in which different weights on thermal comfort and energy consumption based on the energy conservation incentive and price of electricity are placed. Besides, for the distributed MPC method in HVAC systems, the complete experiment is still a gap. The further testing its effects in a real building is another research topic. coredata.dc:description: To meet demands of smart heating development, the novel dynamic regulation methods of heating systems need to be pursued. This paper presents a model predictive control (MPC) approach for room temperature regulation in multi-zone buildings. Among them, a) For heating systems with nonlinearity and large time delay, a hybrid optimization algorithm consisting of the improved particle swarm optimization (IPSO) algorithm and Newton-Raphson (NR) method in online optimization of MPC for a single zone building is proposed. Compared with the quadratic programming method, it can identify successfully the optimal control vector. b) A distributed MPC approach is presented for multi-zone buildings existing hydraulic coupling. Firstly, Nash-optimization acts on searching the global equilibrium point in the distributed structure, then the hybrid optimization algorithm works in the online optimization of these local MPCs. Compared with the decentralized MPC, the control performance is improved through co-operating and communicating between subsystems via network to share information related to their future behavior. Besides, the global performance index in the distributed MPC is redefined as the weighted sum of energy consumption and thermal comfort, which provides the possibility to eliminate quickly the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop in heating systems and reduce energy consumption.
coredata.dc:title: Study on the distributed model predictive control for multi-zone buildings in personalized heating
